subject: Sorry, Saratoga
event:
I don't often attend the World Fantasy Convention (not to be confused with the World Science Fiction Convention, which I have only missed once thirty years), but I was there the last time it was held in Saratoga, and I had a great time. A terrific town, a wonderful con.

This year the convention is returning to Saratoga once again, and I was hoping to return as well. I'm not a guest of honor, and I'm not (so far as I know) getting an award; I just wanted to go.

Reluctantly, however, I've just had to scratch Saratoga off my list of 2015 appearances. For no reason having to do with the con itself. I am sure it will be terrific. It's just a matter of time.

I have too much to do. Too many things on my plate. Son of Kong foremost amongst them.

My apologies to anyone who saw Saratoga on my Appearances page and planned to go in order to see me. I won't be there. Go anyway. You'll have a great time.

Also, I have decided against attending this year's San Diego Comicon. Same reason. But since Comicon was never listed on my Appearances page, scratching it is not as big a deal.

(Should I complete and deliver WINDS OF WINTER before these cons roll round, I reserve the right to change my mind).

comments.article: This isn't right. The thing that everyone loves most about these books is the quality and care with which they are written. If you're sucking the joy out of your life for sake of writing the book something is bound to suffer. Enjoy the cons!
comments.subject: Son of Kong

comments.article: Right on. I don't understand the fans rush to the finish line. I'd rather our author finish the works his way. If he needs time, so be it.
comments.subject: Re: Son of Kong

comments.article:
>Should I complete and deliver WINDS OF WINTER before these cons roll round, I reserve the right to change my mind.

Oh, George. This makes me happy.
comments.subject: Power on, George.

comments.article: Oh the irony of you being happy and George being sad. A story should be made out of this.
comments.subject: Re: Power on, George.

comments.article:
Once you get Winds wrapped, feel free to think of your time as your own.

: - )


(remark about unless 7th book needed redacted)
comments.subject: Re:changing yourmind about convention attendance

comments.article: Is finishing TWOW before the two cons a realistic possibility or are you just mentioning it for the sake of completeness?
comments.subject: Should I...

comments.article: I'm sorry you're disappointed about missing these events.  However you just gave all of us a tremendous amount of hope with your final comment!
comments.subject: Hope! With a side of patience.

comments.article:
DITTO THIS, STEPLATHEM!
You must feel our anticipation and love for your creations. For some of us it has re-shaped our lives and even the way in which we think. Your stories have touched us deeply. Just read the myriad of ASOIAF threads on reddit.com. These cliffhangers have ALL of our panties on a bunch.
comments.subject: Re: CASTING A RATHER LARGE 'HAPPY DANCE' SHADOW

comments.article: Writing about the completion on WoW without it being thrown in your face forcing you to make a comment and talking about WoW completion nonetheless, I am so excited.Thank you George! Must be very close...
comments.subject: Awesome!!

comments.article:
Using this specific example, do you sometimes regret the amount of success you've had that makes it hard to do what you would have liked to do ?

Keeping my fingers and toes crossed for Twow to come out this year. All hail the Mannis!
comments.subject: Any regrets

comments.article:
There are definite drawbacks to success on this level... well, maybe not success, but rather "fame." Starting out, we all dream of being rich and famous. I have to say, rich is great... but fame is definitely a double-edged sword.

But that is hardly an original observation. Still, when it happens to YOU, it is startling.
comments.subject: Re: Any regrets

comments.article:
Im an huge fan of you and your works, from Israel and im truely
Amazed by the way you have managed to create this massive universe, and keep writing
And advancing the plot when there is so many complex elements you need to combine.
How does your method of writing Winds Of Winter looks like?
How do you manage to involve and evolve every character arc in the story? You got so many of them, do you have like notes scattered around your workplace each one contains all the important info about the character?
Anyways, Asoiaf influenced me a lot and everytime i do a reread of the series, i get astounded from the level of comlexity of the series.
Keep doing your best- writing amazing stories, and causing people hooked to your books.
And i think you are going to make it for comicon this year...
comments.subject: Thank you George for your great work!

comments.article: Night gathers, and now our watch begins.
and now our watch BEGINS! SALUTE! (in Italiano-Good Health and Bless you!)

You entertaining the thought of completing Kong Jr in 2015 is the most awesome news of the year so far.

Im sure saratogans will understand.
Doing my best not to get prematurely excited but.... Thank you for writing that last sentence :)
comments.subject: That last sentence...

comments.article: You, Ser, just made my day. It's a shame about the Cons, but the possibility that TWOW might be done this autumn or even summer is huge! Thank you for this!
Godspeed
comments.subject: ah, so...

comments.article: Don't tease us like this. We're too desperate for the next book, especially after Mercy.

... as long as you are still coming to Hamburg in June everything is fine with me. I'll be there ;-).

And if any stupid journalist asks you the question to which the usual answer is 'Tyrion' throw out a 'Runcel Hightower' or 'Septon Murmison'. That should be fun.
comments.subject: Well...

comments.article:
Imagine the relief once TWOW is done and everyone clamoring over it every day can finally STFU for awhile. Until they're finished and you start getting hounded over ADOS.

But still.

And also, this post livened up a massive dump of a day for me, so thanks for that.
comments.subject: Don't be sad!!

comments.article: Oh my. Hype!

You deserve some down time for yourself to do things that you enjoy.You will never not be busy so you might as well go. Please don't be sad. You are the best at your craft and I thank you for everything. :)
comments.subject: You should go and have a great time

comments.article:
>(Should I complete and deliver WINDS OF WINTER before these cons roll round, I reserve the right to change my mind).


Please, no. We enjoy the wait for TWOW. It has been teaching us some valuable skills in life like, patience and the will to not go insane.



But seriously, I love you. Thank you for the sentence ALONE. Can you tell us if the book is actually edited as you're writing it, or will the editing process start after the writing has completely finished?

Thanks!
comments.subject: Thank you.

comments.article:
But seriously Mr. Martin, I did not expect you to say this.

"(Should I complete and deliver WINDS OF WINTER before these cons roll round, I reserve the right to change my mind)" Is that a hint that son of kong nears completion? I know you won't say a thing, but hey, a guy can dream (of spring) can't he?
comments.subject: Sorry that you have to miss your fans...

comments.article:
I'm sorry you are having to sacrifice your freedom, but you will feel so much better once you complete your "to-do list"! :) I would love to attend more cons myself.
Thank you for all the lovely, life enhancing novels you have gifted us! Your sacrifices and hard work do not go unnoticed.
You've made my world a more colorful place.
Respect & blessings,
-Xandria
Do we have permission to take the fact that you consider it even possible to have Son of Kong off your back by ComicCon as a good sign?
I'm sure many of the con-goers feel like Lloyd Christmas right now. In his own words "so you're saying there's a chance?"
comments.subject: Sad to see you miss something you obviously love doing
